An Open, Grassroots Call for Content

We work with designers, content strategists, storytellers, creative agencies, and the entertainment industry to inspire innovative content that speaks to hard-to-count communities. Our work complements the official 2020 Census outreach to ensure a complete and accurate count for everyone in America.

Our Story

Everyone deserves to be counted

Historically, certain groups have been undercounted at disproportionately high rates, including millennials, rural communities, families with young children, immigrants, non-native English speakers, renters, undererepresented minorities, and people experiencing homelessness — these are called “hard-to-count” communities. If these groups aren’t counted, their communities may not receive their fair share of countless services, resources, and representation. It also impacts the data upon which countless policy, legal, and business decisions are made.

330

Million

People to be accounted for in the 2020 Census

We’re finding creative ways to help

We match creatives with community-based Census outreach efforts to generate innovative content that speaks to hard-to-count communities about why their participation matters.

Led by the U.S. Census Bureau, Accelerate works through content development sprints, partnerships, and events to bring together creatives, technologists, civic leaders and community organizers to ensure everyone in our country, regardless of location, income, race or ethnicity, is represented in the 2020 Census.

“Discussing our experiences at the event, we came to a realization. The event had given us more than new materials to use — it left us feeling empowered to create.

Meghan Maury, Policy Director, LGBTQ Taskforce

The 2020 Census

The Decennial Census is a Constitutionally-mandated count of every person living in the United States, once each decade. This population count is used to determine the number of seats each state gets in the U.S. House of Representatives and how to distribute over $675 billion of annual federal funds to states, cities, and local communities for critical infrastructure and services such as housing, highways, schools, hospitals, and more.

New Opportunities New Challenges

Our next Decennial Census begins on April 1, 2020. This Census will count an increasingly diverse and growing population of about 330 million people in more than 140 million housing units, presenting new challenges.

This Census is the first ever “digital” census, which means there’s now an option to fill out each household census online. This is empowering in some ways but there are some real and perceived risks around participation and data security.

The media landscape has changed radically in the last 10 years. With the rise of social news and media fragmentation, there’s a need for more accurate, engaging content on media channels that people use the most in 2020.

Learn More

Here are the groups that have been identified as particularly under-counted or hard-to-count communities in our nation.

  • American Indian and Alaskan Native
  • Black or African American
  • Chinese - Cantonese and Mandarin
  • Low Internet Proficiency
  • LGBTQ
  • Middle Eastern and Pacific Islander (NHPI)
  • Spanish (U.S Mainland)
  • Vietnamese
  • Young and Mobile - Renters, Houseless
  • Families with Kids Under 5

Meet the Team

We’re a group of purpose-driven technologists, creatives and data nerds who believe that a fully counted America is a stronger one.

  • Mara Abrams

    Mara Abrams is the Founder and Co-Director of the Census Open Innovation Labs at the U.S. Census Bureau and the Director of Census Accelerate, where she works with external organizations and networks to build modern and collaborative approaches to solving challenges for the the public, like creating a massive civic mobilization around the Decennial Census.

    Prior to joining the federal government, Mara led Global Partnerships at the Nike Foundation, where she focused on innovation to alleviate poverty for adolescent girls as part of Nike’s Girl Effect initiative. While there, she led the early development of Springster, a mobile platform now reaching 13M unique users in over 50 countries and 13 languages, and the Girl Effect Accelerator, a program to rapidly grow startups with products and services that were changing girls’ lives.

    She is the founder of Cuba's first startup incubator; was a strategist for the Jaguar Land Rover Innovation Lab; led business development for an award-winning organization training citizen journalists in conflict, post-conflict, and underrepresented regions; and co-founded of an organization teaching documentary filmmaking to young people in marginalized communities. She is a 2019 Security Fellow with the Truman National Security Project, a Bloomberg Businessweek Innovation Fellow, and an entrepreneur, speaker, mentor, and advisor with deep expertise at the intersection of impact, innovation, and partnerships. She lives in Los Angeles with her grumpy but loveable schnoodle, Charlie.

  • Drew Zachary

    Drew Zachary is Director/Co-founder of The Opportunity Project and senior User Experience advisor at the US Census Bureau, where she leads open innovation and human centered design initiatives. Previously, Drew was a Policy Advisor at the White House Domestic Policy Council and senior analyst at the Commerce Data Service. Throughout her federal career, Drew has worked with urban, rural and tribal communities to use data, science and technology in support of local economic development goals. At HUD and HHS she designed federal program evaluations and policies to support cities, including the Promise Zones Initiative. Drew has also led design research for technologies to improve healthcare delivery, and urban public health interventions. Drew holds an MPP from Johns Hopkins University and is a PhD candidate in social policy at Brandeis University. Drew's research on technology and program design has been published in Qualitative Health Research, The Diabetes Educator, and eGEMs.

  • Dominica Zhu

    Hi everyone! My name is Dominica Zhu. I was born and raised in New Jersey and now live in Seattle, Washington. I am the Lead Program Manager for COIL. My background is in global development and social entrepreneurship. My most recent projects before COIL include strategizing private sector engagements to improve education in Nepal using technology partnerships, countering human trafficking in Southeast Asia in partnership with USAID, and using digital tools to preserve indigenous knowledge in South Africa and Sri Lanka. A fun fact about me is that I am a Certified Health Coach and nutritionist and also am a Certified BodyTalk Practitioner. I also used to work as a nutritionist on a refugee camp in Ghana. Collaborating with amazing people to solve national/global issues always brings me a ton of fulfillment joy.

  • Lorena Molina-Irizarry

    Lorena Molina-Irizarry serves as Director of Operations at the Census Open Innovation Labs (COIL) within the U.S. Census Bureau; bringing together technologists, communities and government through open collaboration initiatives like The Opportunity Project, to tap into the power of open data, through a start-up like tech accelerator. Previously, she served as the Deputy Chief for National Partnerships, engaging and collaborating with national stakeholders and partners in 2020 Census efforts, other census surveys & programs and increasing data use and awareness of open data. She previously served as the Technology Communications Liaison for the CIO, leading all technology and innovation efforts at the Census Bureau. She has also served as Hispanic Employment Program Manager, implementing outreach and recruitment strategies to reach Hispanic audiences and underrepresented communities.

  • Victoria Fine

    I'm Victoria, a Content Advisor for COIL. Born in Los Angeles, I've lived and worked in dozens of countries and am now happily settled back in Ventura, California. I've made a career of using storytelling and digital media strategy to make socially important messages go viral and have led the growth of media companies at Upworthy, Slate, Huffington Post and elsewhere. Now I do the same through my own agency, Finally, for for nonprofits, fortune 500 companies and of course, the Census! I've my career traveling while working, which included sailing around the East Coast and the Caribbean, and living in Puerto Rico during and after hurricane Maria. So, AMA about remote work, where to go for your next vacation and what to pack in a disaster go-bag. Lastly, I believe everything doing is also worth bringing your whole self to. That means that for me, no workday is complete without having a bit of fun and a good laugh and how seriously we're all taking ourselves. My colleague and life partner is an ornery Chihuahua-mix named Honey Dog who never pulls her weight in our shared home office.

  • Carla Fernandez

    Carla is an experience designer and community weaver focused on building the kinds of relationships - with ourselves, our teams, and our communities - that strengthen ties and help us move forward together. Carla co-founded The Dinner Party, a community of people turning loss from an isolating experience into a source of deep friendship and forward motion by breaking bread - now active in 100+ cities and written about in New York Times, NPR, and OnBeing. She’s a founding team member and former General Manager of creative impact agency enso, leading work with top brands like Google, Mattel, and Nature Conservancy, building a soulful team from Day 0 to 40 people and millions in revenue. She works on impact across industry lines, partnering with the likes of Sheryl Sandberg, Airbnb, the Mayor’s Office of LA, the Federal Census Bureau and acclaimed TV show This Is Us. She lives between Los Angeles and Joshua Tree with her rescue dog Biscotti. More information at carlafernandez.co.

  • Ivan Metzger

An Initiative of Census Open Innovation Labs

COIL’s multifunctional team implements, executes and institutionalizes modern, user-centered methods and innovative approaches to collaboration and partner engagements to reach a complete and accurate count for the 2020 Census and increase awareness, use and adoption of Census data for the public.
